ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I greatly enhanced my ability to read Greek, but most importantly to understand why Greek works the way it does, beyond simply memorizing rules like is done when learning the language. I learned so much about why words are the way they are and why texts are written as they are, as well as the nuances these provide.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class is phenomenal and probably the best I have ever taken at Yale. Prof. Bakker is a linguistic genius and really helps illuminate all these concepts. This class is very difficult--so beware--I would not recommend taking this as a fifth course or even with a fifth course if the rest of the schedule is tough. I feel so much more equipped to read Greek texts after this because of the painstaking practice on prose composition and, most importantly, word study. We also learn a ton about particles--often glossed over--but which provide so much insight about what the author is trying to do. For that alone I would take this class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class operated as well as it could have given the COVID restraints. Everyone had their cameras on and the class was actively engaged.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would strongly recommend this course to anyone who is serious about improving their Ancient Greek. It is NOT easy at all. But it provides so much insight as to why the language works as it does. The class is also brilliantly divided into study of word, study of sentence, and study of text, which provides a holistic view and also ensures that things do not get stale.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
